PAGE.TITLE: Variable separable differential equations
PAGE.DESCRIPTION: In the examples below a method for solving the simplest, variable differential equations is introduced. There are then some examples that allow you to practise using this technique.

EXAMPLE.QUESTION: Solve the following first order differential equation: $$ \frac{\textrm{d} f(x) }{\textrm{d}x } = -\lambda f(x) \qquad \textrm{with} \qquad f(0)=1 $$
EXAMPLE.SOLUTION:
The set of steps we employ in solving this problem are as follows:
We first place all terms in $f(x)$ on the left hand side of the equation and all terms in $x$ on the right hand side. We thus have: $$ \frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{f(x)} = -\lambda \textrm{d}x $$
Next we integrate both sides. Notice that, because of the variable separation, the variable I am integrating over on the right hand side is $f(x)$ and the variable that I am integrating over on the right hand side of the equation is $x$. $$ \int \frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{f(x)} = - \int \lambda \textrm{d}x \qquad \rightarrow \qquad \ln f(x) = - \lambda x + C \qquad \rightarrow \qquad f(x) = Ae^{-\lambda x} $$ There are two things to notice here: [i] Whenever you perform an indefinite integral you must have an additive constant. One could therefore argue that after the integration the left hand side should read $\ln f(x) + B$ and the right hand side should read $-\lambda t + D$. We have combined these two constants into a single constant $C=D-B$, however. [ii] The constant $A$ is equal to $e^{C}$ as in the last step we have taken antilogs of both sides. For the right hand side we thus have: $e^{-\lambda x + C} = e^Ce^{-\lambda x}$
In the final step we use the boundary condition $f(0)=1$ to solve for $A$. We thus have: $$ f(0) = Ae^{0} = 1 \qquad \rightarrow \qquad A \times 1 = 1 \qquad \rightarrow \qquad A=1 $$

EXERCISE.TITLE: Exercise 1
EXERCISE.PROBLEMS:
Solve the following differential equations. If no boundary condition is provided skip the third step that was described in the worked example.
(i) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} \tan x = f(x)$ (ii) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} + f(x) = 1$ (iii) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = ax(1-x) \quad \textrm{with} \quad f(0)=\frac{1}{2}$
(iv) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = e^{-f(x)} \sin x \quad \textrm{with} \quad f(0)=0 \quad$ (v) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = x\tan f(x)$ (vi) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = 3 - 2f(x) \quad \textrm{with} \quad y(0)=1$
(vii) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = \frac{\ln x}{2f(x)} \quad \textrm{with} \quad f(1) = 0$ (viii) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = \frac{f(x)}{x}$
(x) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = g - kf(x) \quad \textrm{with} \quad f(0)=0$ (xi) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = \frac{f(x)+1}{x-1}$ (xii) $[f(x)]^2 \frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = x \quad \textrm{with} \quad f(0)=1$
(xiii) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = e^{2x+y} \quad \textrm{with} \quad f(0)=0$ (xiv) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = \frac{xf(x)}{x+1}$
(xvi) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = -2x \tan f(x)$ (xvii) $(1+x^2) \frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} + xy = 0$
(xx) $\frac{1}{f(x)}\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = \frac{x}{x^2 + 1}$ (xxi) $\frac{\textrm{d}f(x)}{\textrm{d}x} = \frac{f(x)}{x(x+1)} \quad \textrm{with} \quad f(1) = 3$
